name: Valknut

etymology.modernCoinage: The term 'valknut' is a modern Norwegian compound word, not attested in historical sources. The symbol itself appears in Viking Age artifacts without any accompanying name.

description: The Valknut is one of the most recognizable symbols from Norse mythology, consisting of three interlocking triangles. Found on numerous Viking Age artifacts, particularly in funerary contexts, it is strongly associated with Odin, death, and the transition between life and the afterlife. The symbol appears to represent the god's power over life and death, and his role as a psychopomp guiding fallen warriors to Valhalla.

variants.name: Unicursal Valknut
variants.description: A single continuous line forming three interlocking triangles, drawn without lifting the pen

variants.name: Tricursal Valknut (Borromean)
variants.description: Three separate triangles interlocked in a Borromean pattern, where no two triangles are directly linked but all three together are inseparable

numericalSignificance.three: The three triangles may represent the three realms (Asgard, Midgard, Hel), the three Norns, or the threefold nature of existence
numericalSignificance.nine: The nine points correspond to the Nine Worlds of Norse cosmology, connected by Yggdrasil

interpretations.description: The symbol represents Odin's ability to bind and unbind the minds of warriors, granting courage or inflicting terror, and his role in choosing the slain for Valhalla
The Prose Edda describes Hrungnir's heart as 'made of hard stone and pointed with three corners.' Some scholars identify the Valknut with this description
The interlocking nature may symbolize the interconnection of the Nine Worlds or the binding of past, present, and future
Given its funerary context, the symbol may have marked individuals dedicated to Odin through ritual sacrifice or heroic death

archaeologicalEvidence.overview: The Valknut appears on several Viking Age artifacts, predominantly in funerary or sacrificial contexts, supporting its association with death and Odin.

majorFinds.name: Stora Hammars Stones
majorFinds.description: Picture stones depicting scenes including what appears to be human sacrifice. The Valknut appears above a scene showing a man lying on an altar with another figure (possibly a valkyrie) standing over him. Odin's ravens and an eagle are also present.
majorFinds.significance: Strongest evidence linking the symbol to Odin and sacrificial death

majorFinds.name: T칛ngelg친rda Stone

majorFinds.significance: Links the symbol to Odin through Sleipnir imagery

majorFinds.name: Oseberg Ship Burial
majorFinds.description: Elaborate ship burial of two women. The Valknut appears carved on a wooden bedpost among other mythological imagery
majorFinds.significance: High-status funerary context reinforces death association

majorFinds.name: Nene River Ring
majorFinds.description: Anglo-Saxon gold ring bearing a Valknut design

literaryReferences.note: No surviving texts explicitly name or describe the Valknut symbol. All interpretations are based on archaeological context and iconographic analysis.

hrungnirConnection.mythologicalContext: Hrungnir was a j칬tunn (giant) who challenged Odin to a horse race and later fought Thor in single combat. He was described as having a three-cornered stone heart.
hrungnirConnection.theoryDetails: Some scholars propose that the Valknut represents Hrungnir's Heart based on Snorri's description. However, this theory is contested because the symbol appears in contexts relating to Odin rather than giants.
